author: Brandon Schwartz
bottom_line: Avalanche danger will rapidly increase today following the onset of high intensity snowfall later this morning. Rapid new snow accumulation, drifting snow, and rapid loading of existing weak layers in the snowpack are expected to lead to avalanche activity. Travel in, near, or below avalanche terrain is not recommended today.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
Ridgetop winds out of the SW began to increase late yesterday afternoon and are now gale force in speed. Plenty of unconsolidated snow existed on the ground to drift and form new wind slabs last night, especially near treeline. Add to that the expectation that wind slabs will continue to become larger in size today with the drifting of rapidly accumulating new snowfall. The vast majority of wind slabs are expected in above treeline and near treeline terrain across NW-N-NE-E-SE aspects. Wind slabs may form to a lesser degree in below treeline areas due to the strength of the winds. Any wind loaded areas where the slab fails deeper in the snowpack as a persistent slab will allow for deeper, more destructive avalanches with wider propagation.

Travel in, near, or below avalanche terrain is not recommended today.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Wind Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Wind Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer of snow (a slab) formed by the wind. Wind typically transports snow from the upwind sides of terrain features and deposits snow on the downwind side. Wind slabs are often smooth and rounded and sometimes sound hollow, and can range from soft to hard. Wind slabs that form over a persistent weak layer (surface hoar, depth hoar, or near-surface facets) may be termed Persistent Slabs or may develop into Persistent Slabs.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
Weak layers of graupel have persisted on NW-N-NE aspects both above and below treeline. Signs of instability on these weak layers anywhere from 6 inches to 2 feet below the old snow surface were observed yesterday in the form of snow surface cracking and unstable snowpit test results. Two skier triggered avalanches occurred yesterday in the Ward Canyon area with snowpack failure reported 6 to 8 inches below the snow surface. While the weak layer in these avalanches is unconfirmed, there is a good chance these avalanches were persistent slabs.

Rapid additional loading of new snow today is expected to add further stress to this weak layer. As more new snow is added to the upper snowpack, potential avalanche size will increase. Persistent slab avalanches are expected to have wide propagation regardless of slab depth. Travel in, near, or below avalanche terrain is not recommended today.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Persistent Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Persistent Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer of snow (a slab) in the middle to upper snowpack, when the bond to an underlying persistent weak layer breaks. Persistent layers include: surface hoar, depth hoar, near-surface facets, or faceted snow. Persistent weak layers can continue to produce avalanches for days, weeks or even months, making them especially dangerous and tricky. As additional snow and wind events build a thicker slab on top of the persistent weak layer, this avalanche problem may develop into a Deep Persistent Slab.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion: High intensity snowfall today may lead to slabs of unstable storm snow failing at or above the old/new snow interface in wind protected areas. This avalanche problem will become a concern this afternoon with potential avalanche size increasing late day.
forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Storm Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Storm Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer (a slab) of new snow that breaks within new snow or on the old snow surface. Storm-slabs typically last between a few hours and few days (following snowfall). Storm-slabs that form over a persistent weak layer (surface hoar, depth hoar, or near-surface facets) may be termed Persistent Slabs or may develop into Persistent Slabs.
